definition[0]: when there is confusion about something, and things are done wrong as a result
example[0]: Our accountant finally managed to sort out the muddle.
example[1]: There was a bit of a muddle over our hotel reservations.
definition[1]: to put things in the wrong order
example[2]: Someone’s muddled up all the papers on my desk.
example[3]: The government seems to have lost its way and muddled its priorities.
definition[2]: to confuse one person or thing with another, and make a mistake
example[4]: The twins are so alike that it’s easy to muddle them up.
example[5]: Spanish and Italian are very similar and I sometimes get them muddled up.
example[6]: Be careful not to muddle the files you’ve already worked on with the others.
definition[3]: to confuse someone, especially so that they make a mistake
example[7]: Don’t muddle her with all the extra details at the moment.
example[8]: Could you just repeat those figures – I’ve got a bit muddled up.
